form.desc: This describes a relationship of mutual antagonism and should always take mutual, not active and passive. Should a relationship be encountered in which the antagonism is in one direction only, a different name value will be needed; but to date no entry has referred to such a relationship.
The relationship between a nurse and the child she is nursing

This describes the relationship identified by Forman as existing between him and Anne Waller, whom he described as his ‘mother’ but who was not his biological parent. The precise nature of the relationship being claimed is unclear.
It is very unlikely that any similar examples will be found in the remaining cases
A menial servant who carries coal

When Napier uses the term ‘son-in-law’ he sometimes means what we would call ‘stepson’. Where there is some clear indication that this is the case, the name value stepson should instead be used, with evidence indicating where the information comes from

When Napier uses the term ‘daughter-in-law’ he sometimes means what we would call ‘stepdaughter’. Where there is some clear indication that this is the case, the name value stepdaughter should instead be used, with evidence indicating where the information comes from
Chaplain qua ecclesiastical inferior.

This is a relationship (to be recorded in the header only when the word is explicitly used in the text) between two or more people from the same part of the country (such as the same county). If the people so related are all of the same sex then this takes mutual; if they are of different sexes then it takes active and passive.
The relationship between the nurse and the parents of the child she is nursing
This is the relationship between the head of a household and a member or members of that household.
This is the relationship between a member of a household and the head of that household.
This covers the terms ‘kinsman’, ‘cousin’ and ‘cognatus’
This covers the terms ‘kinswoman’, ‘cousin’ and ‘cognata’
This covers vague familial terms such as ‘cousin’ or ‘kind’, or perhaps ‘cogn.’ (abbreviated from ‘cognatus’ or ‘cognata’), where there is no information as to the person’s gender.
Chaplain qua minister of the church.

When Napier uses the term ‘father-in-law’ he sometimes means what we would call ‘stepfather’. Where there is some clear indication that this is the case, the name value stepfather should instead be used, with evidence indicating where the information comes from

When Napier uses the term ‘mother-in-law’ he sometimes means what we would call ‘stepmother’. Where there is some clear indication that this is the case, the name value stepmother should instead be used, with evidence indicating where the information comes from

This describes the relationship identified by Forman as existing between him and Anne Waller, whom he described as his ‘mother’ but who was not his biological parent. The precise nature of the relationship being claimed is unclear.
It is very unlikely that any similar examples will be found in the remaining cases

This takes mutual and describes a relationship in which the (two) participants are in love with each other. Where one party is in love but the other not, or possibly not, the name value wouldBeSweetheart should be used instead.

To be used for anyone who serves someone else in a general capacity, whether they are described in occupation as a servant, man, maid, boy, waiting gentlewoman, or any similar term; the exception is retainers, for whom the name retainer should be used. This can include people of very high status who serve those of even higher status: if Mr X is described as Sir YZ’s man then the relationship should be encoded as servant; likewise if Sir YZ is described as Lord AB’s man. Such high-status people should not, however, be given an occupation of ‘Servant’, ‘Man (Servant)’ etc. Within the casebooks we find two overlapping but distinct senses of ‘servant’: an older sense in which society is hierarchical and everyone serves someone else all the way up to the monarch; and a newer sense in which the term ‘servant’ denotes a person doing a particular low-status job. To deal with these different meanings of the term, we use the relation servant for service at all levels of society, but do not use the occupation ‘Servant’ to describe high-status people.
The relationship between the master of the ship and the ship (encoded as an org)
The relationship between a captain and his ship (encoded as an org)

Sometimes used by Napier to mean brother-in-law. If this is the case, the name value should instead be brother-in-law, with evidence specified to indicate where the information comes from that it is brother-in-law rather than brother

Sometimes used by Napier to mean sister-in-law. If this is the case, the name value should instead be sister-in-law, with evidence specified to indicate where the information comes from that it is sister-in-law rather than sister

Unlike mother-in-law and father-in-law, brother-in-law as used by Napier means the same thing as the modern term. However, he often writes ‘brother’ where we would say brother-in-law. If Napier uses the term brother and means brother-in-law, the relation should be given as brother-in-law, with evidence specifying where the information comes from that he is an in-law

Unlike mother-in-law and father-in-law, sister-in-law as used by Napier means the same thing as the modern term. However, he often writes ‘sister’ where we would say sister-in-law. If Napier uses the term sister and means sister-in-law, the relation should be given as sister-in-law, with evidence specifying where the information comes from that she is an in-law
Napier often uses the term ‘son-in-law’ to mean stepson
Napier often uses the term ‘daughter-in-law’ to mean stepdaughter
Napier often uses the term ‘father-in-law’ to mean stepfather
Napier often uses the term ‘mother-in-law’ to mean stepmother
The relationship between an organisation or institution’s officer and that organisation or institution (encoded as an org)
Commercial agent; given in the text as ‘worker’

Apprenticeship is taken as a type of relationship rather than an occupation. Where A is described as B’s apprentice, they should be given the relation ‘apprentice’. If someone is described as an apprentice bookbinder, the person’s occupation should be given as bookbinder, then they should be made the apprentice of a second (anonymous) person, whose occupation should also be made bookbinder
An austringer works with hawks. This has been used to indicate a relationship in which person A was the keeper of person B’s hawks (along with the occupation ‘Keeper of hawks’)
Takes mutual; including ‘contracted’ used in the marital sense, ‘made sure to be his wife’, etc
As in ‘counsellor-at-law’, legal adviser
Curate qua minister of the church
Curate qua ecclesiastical inferior
This describes the relationship between the dairymaid and the mistress or master for whom she works
Describing a relationship between the dry nurse and the parents of the child she is nursing
This is specifically for the explicit term ‘first cousin’; more general references to ‘cousin’ should be given the name value kinsman, kinswoman or kinswoman_kinsman.

Being a journeyman is for our purposes (and like apprenticeship) taken as a type of relationship rather than an occupation. Where A is described as B’s journeyman, they should be given the relation ‘journeyman’. If someone is described as a journeyman bookbinder, the person’s occupation should be given as bookbinder, then they should be made the journeyman of a second (anonymous) person, whose occupation should also be made bookbinder
The relationship between a licensee and the body licensing him, so far specifically the College of Physicians
The relationship between a soldier and his captain; for the relationship between the captain of a ship and his ship, see shipCaptain.
The relationship between a ship’s owner and the ship (encoded as an org)

This describes (as far as we know) the relationship between a ploughboy and his mistress/master or employer. Any instances encountered in which the relationship described is that between the ploughboy and a ploughman with whom he works should be referred to the senior editors as they may mean we need to divide this into two.
Note that retained servants do not live in
This is the relationship between a schoolmaster and his pupil; cf. schoolmasterEmployee, which is the relationship between a schoolmaster and his employer.
This is the relationship between a schoolmaster and his employer; cf. schoolmasterEducator, which is the relationship between a schoolmaster and his employer.
This is the relationship between a servant within a household, and that servant’s superior (another servant) within the same household.
The relationship between the captain of the ship and the ship (encoded as an org). For the relationship between a soldier and his captain, see militaryCaptain
The relationship between a tapster (which should be recorded as an occupation) and his or her employer.
This should not be used. It is a duplicate of under-butler and will be removed after the site’s next update.
This is the relationship between an under-sheriff and the sheriff for whom he works.

This is specifically for a romantic relationship that is asymmetric, or potentially asymmetric: that is, one in which person A is attracted to or in love with person B but the reverse is not (or may not be) true. In that situation, active should point at the xml:id of person A, and passive at the xml:id of person B. Reciprocated relationships, in which two people are in love with each other, should be encoded using romanticPartner instead.
A rank of servant or attendant in a noble household between a sergeant and a groom, or between a squire and a page; or an attendant or assistant to an official.
